Award.AwardTitle: 1% accuracy in fundamental stellar parameters? Not without an extensive redesign of eclipsing binary models.
Award.AbstractNarration:
Eclipsing binary stars can be used to determine the radius and mass of stars by relying on simple geometry and well understood laws of physics. Observations obtained over the last decade have greatly improved in accuracy, so the theoretical models used to interpret these data require substantial revision. This project identifies the aspects of theoretical models in need of revision and proposes a path to update the models. This will enable accurate (within 1%) measurements of stellar masses and radii. Precise determination of fundamental stellar properties is critical to many branches of astrophysics, from studying the life cycles of stars to determining distances throughout the universe. The advances in modelling approaches and classification are applicable to many problems in astronomy, physics, engineering, and applied mathematics. Conducting this program at a primarily undergraduate institution will provide opportunities undergraduate students learn modern research tools and techniques.

The investigators will develop the following improvements to their eclipsing binary modelling codes: (a) optimize stellar surface discretization to mitigate systematics in distorted systems and to be able to model more complicated structures such as accretion disks; (b) systematically treat Doppler boosting for all modelled binaries; (c) devise a numerical framework for the Generalized Roche Potential that will allow for tilted spin axes of components to the orbital axis; (d) rigorously treat multiple body systems, predicting eclipse timing variations, tertiary eclipses, dynamical interactions of extended bodies, and other related phenomena; (e) revise the limb darkening treatment to resolve the ingress/egress fitting problems and, consequently, eliminate systematics from the determination of stellar radii; (f) implement a new morphological classification scheme based on modern embedding algorithms; (g) provide a new formalism for statistical error estimates using Markov Chain Monte Carlo methods and Bayesian inference to resolve a long-standing issue of underestimated parameter errors; (h) account for finite integration time corrections; and (i) write a back-end in python that will allow code parallelization in high performance computing and make it available to the broader astronomical community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How do astronomers determine the masses and radii of stars in the Universe? To appreciate the gravity of this question, consider that light from the nearest star past the Sun travels 4.3 years to reach us here on Earth. To put that in perspective, if our Sun were a basketball in Key West, Florida, then the nearest star, Proxima Centauri, would be a billiard ball in Seattle, Washington, some 3500 miles away. And that is just the nearest star -- the vast majority of other stars -- basketballs, that is -- would not even be on or near Earth anymore. So how do we measure the size of a billiard ball in Seattle and beyond from a speck orbiting a basketball in Key West? Easy: by using eclipsing binary stars.

Eclipsing binary stars are systems of two stars orbiting their mutual center of mass, where their orbit is aligned with our line of sight from Earth, causing the stars to mutually eclipse one another. We observe a change in brightness as a function of time -- the system will appear brighter when both stars are visible and fainter when either star is eclipsed by its companion. If we plot this change of brightness as a function of time, we obtain a light curve. From the shape and duration of the dip we can work out the sizes of the two stars, and from the time it takes for the stars to make one full revolution, and how large are their orbits with respect to their center of mass, we can work out the masses of the two stars.

Of course, stars are not round inflated sports balls, which further complicates things. The brightness across stellar disks is not uniform because of the limb darkening effect; the shape of the stellar surfaces is not spherical, it is deformed by gravity, tides and rotation into an asymmetrically oblate ellipsoid, further changing the disk brightness distribution; a slew of relativistic effects also plays a role that further affect the amount of light we intercept and use to infer the sizes and masses of binary system components. And then there are spots, pulsations, complex radiation properties, accretion disks, etc.

Thus, to reach 1% in these fundamental parameters, we need to be able to account for all the mentioned effects. We do so by incorporating them into the modeling suite called PHOEBE, a principal deliverable of this NSF-funded project. PHOEBE (PHysics Of Eclipsing BinariEs; http://phoebe-project.org) is a code that takes a number of parameters as input, such as orbital inclination, temperatures of both stars, their separation, etc, and it computes synthetic observables, such as light curves, as output. All that remains to be done is to figure out what values of the input parameters will yield a light curve that is as similar to what is observed.

Figuring out similarity comes with its own set of problems. Computing light curves from a set of parameters is a highly non-linear problem, which means that many combinations of parameters result in indistinguishable light curves. Yet we are tasked to find only the combinations that are physically plausible and most likely. To this end we employ probabilistic inference methods to derive posterior probability density estimators for each inferred parameter. This provides us with a probabilistic description of parameters, telling us how reliable our estimates are given the available data. To do this inference correctly, we need to deploy PHOEBE on a high performance computing cluster.

This NSF award allowed us to build an advanced framework for modeling eclipsing binary stars that has become one of the de-facto standards in astronomy. The impact of this research is best gauged by the fact that stars are building blocks of the entire visible universe, and measuring their masses and radii as precisely as possible remains at the forefront of modern astrophysics. Our work continues to push the current limits -- we are already at ~1% -- but our ultimate goal is to reduce the uncertainties in parameters obtained from state-of-the-art observations to below 0.1%. We sincerely hope that NSF will join us for this exciting ride in the future as well.
